prompt:
The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['ChoralConductor/1', 'Musician/1', 'SpecializedIn/2', 'PublishedBook/2', 'LoveMusic/1']

---

Now, let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map:

**Premises:**
1. `∀x (ChoralConductor(x) → Musician(x))`
2. `∃x (Musician(x) ∧ LoveMusic(x))`
3. `ChoralConductor(MiroslavVenhoda)`
4. `ChoralConductor(MiroslavVenhoda) ∧ SpecializedIn(MiroslavVenhoda, RenaissanceAndBaroqueMusic)`
5. `PublishedBook(MiroslavVenhoda, MethodOfStudyingGregorianChantIn1946)`

**Conclusion:**
`¬∃x (ChoralConductor(x) ∧ SpecializedIn(x, Renaissance))`

These expressions can now be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises. 

<PREMISES>
All dispensable things are environment-friendly.
All woodware is dispensable.
All paper is woodware.
No good things are bad.
All environment-friendly things are good.
A worksheet is either paper or is environment-friendly.
</PREMISES>
<CONCLUSION>
A worksheet is not dispensable.
</CONCLUSION>
<EVALUATE>
Predicate/arity map for the problem: 
 ['Bad/1', 'Dispensable/1', 'EnvironmentFriendly/1', 'Good/1', 'Paper/1', 'Woodware/1']TEXT: All dispensable things are environment-friendly. 
FOL: all x. (Dispensable(x) -> EnvironmentFriendly(x))
TEXT: All woodware is dispensable.
FOL: all x. (Woodware(x) -> Dispensable(x))
TEXT: All paper is woodware. 
FOL: all x. (Paper(x) -> Woodware(x))
TEXT: No good things are bad. 
FOL: all x. (Good(x) -> -Bad(x))
TEXT: All environment-friendly things are good.
FOL: all x. (EnvironmentFriendly(x) -> Good(x))
TEXT: A worksheet is either paper or is environment-friendly.
FOL: ((Paper(Worksheet) & -EnvironmentFriendly(Worksheet)) | (-Paper(Worksheet) & EnvironmentFriendly(Worksheet)))
TEXT: A worksheet is not dispensable.
FOL: -Dispensable(Worksheet)
</EVALUATE>

<PREMISES>
A La Liga soccer team ranks higher than another if it receives more points.
If two La Liga soccer teams recieve the same points, the team which recieves more points from the games between the two teams ranks higher.
Real Madrid and Barcelona are both La Liga soccer teams.
In La Liga 2021-2022, Real Madrid recieves 86 points and Barcelon recieves 73 points.
In La Liga 2021-2022, Real Madrid and Barcelona both recieve 3 points from the games between them.
</PREMISES>
<CONCLUSION>
In La Liga 2021-2022, Real Madrid ranks higher than Barcelona.
</CONCLUSION>
<EVALUATE>
Predicate/arity map for the problem: 
 ['HigherRank/2', 'LaLiga/1', 'MorePoints/2', 'MorePointsInGameBetween/2']TEXT: A La Liga soccer team ranks higher than another if it receives more points.
FOL: all x. all y. (LaLiga(x) & LaLiga(y) & MorePoints(x, y) -> HigherRank(x, y))
TEXT: If two La Liga soccer teams recieve the same points, the team which recieves more points from the games between the two teams ranks higher.
FOL: all x. all y. (LaLiga(x) & LaLiga(y) & -MorePoints(x, y) & -MorePoints(y, x) & MorePointsInGameBetween(x, y) -> HigherRank(x, y))
TEXT: Real Madrid and Barcelona are both La Liga soccer teams.
FOL: LaLiga(RealMadrid) & LaLiga(Barcelona)
TEXT: In La Liga 2021-2022, Real Madrid recieves 86 points and Barcelon recieves 73 points.
FOL: MorePoints(RealMadrid, Barcelona)
TEXT: In La Liga 2021-2022, Real Madrid and Barcelona both recieve 3 points from the games between them.
FOL: -MorePointsInGameBetween(RealMadrid, Barcelona) & -MorePointsInGameBetween(Barcelona, RealMadrid)
TEXT: In La Liga 2021-2022, Real Madrid ranks higher than Barcelona.
FOL: HigherRank(RealMadrid, Barcelona)
</EVALUATE>

<PREMISES>
Every chef can cook.
Some people who aren’t chefs can cook.
People who cook can make scrambled eggs and pasta.
If someone can make cookies and muffins, they are a baker.
Bakers who can also make scrambled eggs can make a good breakfast.

<CONCLUSION>
Luke can make a good breakfast.
</CONCLUSION>
<EVALUATE>
Predicate/arity map for the problem: 
 ['Baker/1', 'Chef/1', 'Cook/1', 'MakeCookies/1', 'MakeGoodBreakfast/1', 'MakeMuffins/1', 'MakePasta/1', 'MakeScrambledEggs/1']TEXT: Every chef can cook.
FOL: all x. (Chef(x) -> Cook(x))
TEXT: Some people who aren’t chefs can cook.
FOL: exists x. (-Chef(x) & Cook(x))
TEXT: People who cook can make scrambled eggs and pasta.
FOL: all x. (Cook(x) -> (MakeScrambledEggs(x) & MakePasta(x)))
TEXT: If someone can make cookies and muffins, they are a baker.
FOL: all x. (MakeCookies(x) & MakeMuffins(x) -> Baker(x))
TEXT: Bakers who can also make scrambled eggs can make a good breakfast.
FOL: all x. ((Baker(x) & MakeScrambledEggs(x)) -> MakeGoodBreakfast(x))
TEXT: Luke can make cookies, scrambled eggs, and muffins, but not pasta.
FOL: MakeCookies(Luke) & MakeScrambledEggs(Luke) & MakeMuffins(Luke) & -MakePasta(Luke)
TEXT: Luke can make a good breakfast.
FOL: MakeGoodBreakfast(Luke)
</EVALUATE>

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['Fish/1', 'StingsPeople/1', 'Stonefish/1', 'TreatsSting/2', 'CausesDeath/2']

Now, let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map.

**Premises:**
1. Some fish stings people.
   - `exists x (Fish(x) ∧ StingsPeople(x))`
2. Stonefish is a fish.
   - `Stonefish/1(x) → Fish(x)`
3. Stonefish stings when stepped on.
   - `Stonefish(x) → StingsPeople(x)`
4. If a stonefish stings someone and they are not treated, it can cause death to them.
   - `Stonefish(x) ∧ StingsPeople(x) ∧ ¬TreatsSting(x, y) → CausesDeath(y)`
5. To treat stonefish stings, apply heat to the affected area or use an antivenom.
   - `TreatsSting(Stonefish(x), y) → (HeatTreatment(y) ∨ Antivenom(y))`

**Conclusion:**
- Stings of some fish can cause death if not treated.
  - `exists x (Fish(x) ∧ StingsPeople(x) ∧ ¬TreatsSting(x, y) → CausesDeath(y))`

These FOL expressions can now be input into a theorem solver like Prover9 to check if the conclusion logically follows from the premises.

These translations can now be input into a theorem prover like Prover9 to check if the conclusion logically follows from the premises.

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem: 
['District/2', 'City/1']

---

Now, let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map:

### Premises:
1. **Xiufeng, Xiangshan, Diecai, Qixing are districts in the city of Guilin.**
   - `District('Xiufeng', 'Guilin')`
   - `District('Xiangshan', 'Guilin')`
   - `District('Diecai', 'Guilin')`
   - `District('Qixing', 'Guilin')`

2. **Yangshuo is not a district in Guilin.**
   - `~District('Yangshuo', 'Guilin')`

### Conclusion:
- **Xiangshan and Diecai are districts in the same city.**
  - `City('Xiangshan', 'Diecai')` or `City('Diecai', 'Xiangshan')`

Given the structure of the problem, we don't need to express that they are in the same city explicitly since the fact that they are both districts in Guilin already implies this. However, if you want to formalize it further, you could use the `City/1` predicate to ensure they are in the same city:

- `City('Xiangshan', 'Guilin') ∧ City('Diecai', 'Guilin')`

So, the final FOL expressions would be:

### Premises:
```
District('Xiufeng', 'Guilin')
District('Xiangshan', 'Guilin')
District('Diecai', 'Guilin')
District('Qixing', 'Guilin')
~District('Yangshuo', 'Guilin')
```

### Conclusion:
```
City('Xiangshan', 'Guilin') ∧ City('Diecai', 'Guilin')
```

These expressions can now be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine if the conclusion logically follows from the premises.

The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.

['Electronic/1', 'Iphone/1', 'Phone/1']

Premises:
1. \(\forall x (Iphone(x) \rightarrow Electronic(x))\)
2. \(\exists x (Phone(x) \land Iphone(x))\)

Conclusion:
3. \(\forall x (Phone(x) \rightarrow \neg Electronic(x))\)

Let's break down the translation:

1. **All iPhones are electronic:**
   \[
   \forall x (Iphone(x) \rightarrow Electronic(x))
   \]

2. **Some phones are iPhones:**
   \[
   \exists x (Phone(x) \land Iphone(x))
   \]

3. **No phones are electronic:**
   \[
   \forall x (Phone(x) \rightarrow \neg Electronic(x))
   \]

These FOL expressions can now be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['DrainageBasin/2', 'In/2', 'FlowsTo/2']
---
Now, let's translate the premises and the conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map:

### Stage 1: Premises

1. **All dispensable things are environment-friendly.**
   - \( \forall x \text{ Dispensable}(x) \rightarrow \text{EnvironmentFriendly}(x) \)

2. **All woodware is dispensable.**
   - \( \forall x \text{ Woodware}(x) \rightarrow \text{Dispensable}(x) \)

3. **All paper is woodware.**
   - \( \forall x \text{ Paper}(x) \rightarrow \text{Woodware}(x) \)

4. **No good things are bad.**
   - \( \forall x (\text{Good}(x) \rightarrow \neg \text{Bad}(x)) \)

5. **All environment-friendly things are good.**
   - \( \forall x (\text{EnvironmentFriendly}(x) \rightarrow \text{Good}(x)) \)

6. **A worksheet is either paper or is environment-friendly.**
   - \( \forall x (\text{Worksheet}(x) \rightarrow (\text{Paper}(x) \lor \text{EnvironmentFriendly}(x))) \)

### Stage 2: Conclusion

**A worksheet is not dispensable.**
- \( \forall x (\text{Worksheet}(x) \rightarrow \neg \text{Dispensable}(x)) \)

### Stage 1: Premises

1. **All athletes are good at sports.**

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['IsPositive/1', 'IsDoubleOf/2', 'LargerThan/2', 'RealNumber/1', 'PlusOne/2']

---

Now, let's translate the premises and the conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map:

**Premises:**

1. Six, seven and eight are real numbers.
   - `RealNumber(six)`  
   - `RealNumber(seven)`  
   - `RealNumber(eight)`

2. If a real number equals another real number added by one, the first number is larger.
   - `LargerThan(X, PlusOne(Y)) -> IsPositive(X)`

3. If the number x is larger than the number y, then y is not larger than x.
   - `LargerThan(X, Y) -> Not(LargerThan(Y, X))`

4. Seven equals six plus one.
   - `seven = PlusOne(six)`

5. Eight equals seven plus one.
   - `eight = PlusOne(seven)`

6. Two is positive.
   - `IsPositive(two)`

7. If a number is positive, then the double of it is also positive.
   - `IsPositive(X) -> IsDoubleOf(Doubled(X), X)`

8. Eight is the double of four.
   - `IsDoubleOf(eight, four)`

9. Four is the double of two.
   - `IsDoubleOf(four, two)`

**Conclusion:**

1. Eight is positive.
   - `IsPositive(eight)`

These translations should be compatible with the Python NLTK package logic module and can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.

prompt:
The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['RealNumber/1', 'Larger/2', 'Positive/1', 'DoubleOf/2']

---

Now let's translate the premises and the conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map:

### Premises

1. Six, seven and eight are real numbers.
   - \( \text{RealNumber}(6) \)
   - \( \text{RealNumber}(7) \)
   - \( \text{RealNumber}(8) \)

2. If a real number equals another real number added by one, the first number is larger.
   - \( \forall x \forall y (\text{RealNumber}(x) \land \text{RealNumber}(y) \land x = y + 1 \rightarrow \text{Larger}(x, y)) \)

3. If the number \( x \) is larger than the number \( y \), then \( y \) is not larger than \( x \).
   - \( \forall x \forall y (\text{Larger}(x, y) \rightarrow \neg \text{Larger}(y, x)) \)

4. Seven equals six plus one.
   - \( 7 = 6 + 1 \)
   - \( \text{RealNumber}(6) \land \text{RealNumber}(7) \land 7 = 6 + 1 \)

5. Eight equals seven plus one.
   - \( 8 = 7 + 1 \)
   - \( \text{RealNumber}(7) \land \text{RealNumber}(8) \land 8 = 7 + 1 \)

6. Two is positive.
   - \( \text{Positive}(2) \)

7. If a number is positive, then the double of it is also positive.
   - \( \forall x (\text{Positive}(x) \rightarrow \text{Positive}(\text{DoubleOf}(x, x))) \)

8. Eight is the double of four.
   - \( \text{DoubleOf}(8, 4) \)

9. Four is the double of two.
   - \( \text{DoubleOf}(4, 2) \)

### Conclusion

1. Six is larger than seven.
   - \( \text{Larger}(6, 7) \)

### Evaluation

We need to determine if the conclusion \( \text{Larger}(6, 7) \) follows from the premises. We can use a theorem prover like Prover9 to check this. Here are the translated expressions in a format that can be directly input into Prover9:

```
% Premises
(RealNumber(6))
(RealNumber(7))
(RealNumber(8))
(∀x∀y((RealNumber(x) ∧ RealNumber(y) ∧ x = y + 1) → Larger(x, y)))
(∀x∀y((Larger(x, y) → ¬Larger(y, x))))
(RealNumber(6) ∧ RealNumber(7) ∧ 7 = 6 + 1)
(RealNumber(7) ∧ RealNumber(8) ∧ 8 = 7 + 1)
(Positive(2))
(∀x((Positive(x) → Positive(DoubleOf(x, x)))))
(DoubleOf(8, 4))
(DoubleOf(4, 2))

% Conclusion
(Larger(6, 7))
```

This set of FOL expressions can be fed into a theorem prover like Prover9 to check if the conclusion follows logically from the premises.

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

['BenefitFromWork/2', 'GroupWork/2', 'IntangibleBenefits/1', 'NaturalDisasterResponse/1', 'RegularlyWork/1', 'Trained/1', 'Volunteer/1', 'WorkAsNeeded/1']

---

Now, let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map:

### Premises:
1. All volunteers receive intangible benefits for their work.
   - ∀x (Volunteer(x) → BenefitFromWork(x, IntangibleBenefits))

2. Volunteers work regularly or on an as-needed basis.
   - ∀x (Volunteer(x) → (RegularlyWork(x) ∨ WorkAsNeeded(x)))

3. Some volunteers are trained.
   - ∃x (Volunteer(x) ∧ Trained(x))

4. Volunteers work in groups or individually.
   - ∀x (Volunteer(x) → (GroupWork(x, Volunteering) ∨ ¬GroupWork(x, Volunteering)))

5. Environmental volunteers contribute toward environmental management or conservation.
   - ∀x (Volunteer(x) ∧ Environmental(x) → (EnvironmentalManagement(x) ∨ Conservation(x)))

6. Participating in natural disaster response is an example of volunteers working in groups on an as-needed basis.
   - NaturalDisasterResponse(x) → GroupWork(x, Volunteering) ∧ WorkAsNeeded(x)

### Conclusion:
Volunteers who participate in natural disaster response receive intangible benefits for their work.
- ∀x (NaturalDisasterResponse(x) → BenefitFromWork(x, IntangibleBenefits))

This translation should allow the expression to be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem: 
['Village/1', 'CivilParish/1', 'LocatedIn/2', 'District/1', 'County/1', 'Country/1']

---

Now, let's translate the premises and the conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map. We'll use the `nltk` package format for the FOL expressions.

### Premises:

1. Ainderby Quernhow is a village and civil parish in the Hambleton District.
   - `Village(AinderbyQuernhow) ∧ CivilParish(AinderbyQuernhow) ∧ LocatedIn(AinderbyQuernhow, HambletonDistrict)`
   
2. Hambleton District is in North Yorkshire.
   - `LocatedIn(HambletonDistrict, NorthYorkshire)`

3. North Yorkshire is in England.
   - `LocatedIn(NorthYorkshire, England)`

4. If place A is located in place B and place B is located in place C, then place A is located in place C.
   - `((LocatedIn(A, B) ∧ LocatedIn(B, C)) → LocatedIn(A, C))`

### Conclusion:
- There is a village in England.
  - `∃x (Village(x) ∧ LocatedIn(x, England))`

These FOL expressions can now be input into a theorem prover like Prover9 to check if the conclusion logically follows from the premises.

The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem: 
['American/1', 'ComputerScientist/1', 'Mathematician/1', 'ProfessorEmeritus/2', 'CalledFatherOfAnalysisOfAlgorithms/1']

---

Now, let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map.

**Premises:**
1. Donald Ervin Knuth is an American computer scientist, mathematician, and Professor Emeritus at Stanford University.
   - `American(Knuth) ∧ ComputerScientist(Knuth) ∧ Mathematician(Knuth) ∧ ProfessorEmeritus(Knuth, StanfordUniversity)`
2. Knuth has been called the "father of the analysis of algorithms."
   - `CalledFatherOfAnalysisOfAlgorithms(Knuth)`

**Conclusion:**
- An American scientist has been called the "father of the analysis of algorithms".
  - `∃x (American(x) ∧ ComputerScientist(x) → CalledFatherOfAnalysisOfAlgorithms(x))`

These expressions can now be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.

2. **Premise:** Knuth has been called the "father of the analysis of algorithms."
   - FOL Expression: \( \text{CalledFatherOfAnalysisOfAlgorithms}(\text{Knuth}) \)

### Stage 2: Translating Conclusion

1. **Conclusion:** A mathematician has been called the "father of the analysis of algorithms."

### Summary of Expressions

- **Predicates/Arity:**

  - `CalledFatherOfAnalysisOfAlgorithms/1`

- **Premises:**

  - \( \text{CalledFatherOfAnalysisOfAlgorithms}(\text{Knuth}) \)

- **Conclusion:**

These FOL expressions can now be input into a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine if the conclusion follows from the premises.

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['Produced/2', 'PeakAtNo1/2', 'Popular/1']

Explanation of the predicates:
- `Produced(WhiteTown, song)` indicates that White Town produced the song.
- `PeakAtNo1(song, place)` indicates that the song peaked at No. 1 in the specified place.
- `Popular(song)` indicates that the song was popular.

The predicates are kept simple and directly related to the information provided in the premises. There is no redundancy or unnecessary length in the predicate names.

Now, let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions using these predicates:

**Premises:**
1. "Your Woman" is a song by the British one-person band White Town.
   - `Produced(WhiteTown, YourWoman)`
2. "Your Woman" song peaked at No. 1 on the UK Singles Chart.
   - `PeakAtNo1(YourWoman, UK)`
3. If a song peaked at No. 1 at a particular place, it was extremely popular.
   - `PeakAtNo1(song, place) -> Popular(song)`
4. "Your Woman" peaked at No. 1 in Iceland, Israel, and Spain.
   - `PeakAtNo1(YourWoman, Iceland)`
   - `PeakAtNo1(YourWoman, Israel)`
   - `PeakAtNo1(YourWoman, Spain)`

**Conclusion:**
- White Town did not produce any popular songs.
  - `~(Popular(song) & Produced(WhiteTown, song))` (for all songs)

This translation can be input into a theorem prover like Prover9 to determine if the conclusion logically follows from the premises.

prompt:
The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['Scored/3', 'PenaltyShootOut/2', 'RegularTime/0', 'ExtraTime/0', 'UCLFinal/1']

---

Now, let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions:

### Premises:
1. If two soccer teams score the same number of goals in one UCL final during the regular time, they need to play for the extra time.
   - \( \forall x \forall y (Scored(x, y, RegularTime()) \land Scored(y, x, RegularTime()) \rightarrow NeedExtraTime(x, y)) \)
   - Where \(NeedExtraTime(x, y)\) is a shorthand for "they need to play for the extra time."

2. If two soccer teams score the same number of goals in one UCL final during both regular and extra time, they need to play the penalty shoot-out.
   - \( \forall x \forall y (Scored(x, y, RegularTime()) \land Scored(x, y, ExtraTime()) \land Scored(y, x, RegularTime()) \land Scored(y, x, ExtraTime()) \rightarrow NeedPenaltyShootOut(x, y)) \)

3. Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid both scored one goal in the 2016 UCL final during the regular time.
   - \( Scored(RealMadrid, Atl\u00E9ticoMadrid, RegularTime()) \land Scored(Atl\u00E9ticoMadrid, RealMadrid, RegularTime()) \land \text{2016UCLFinal}() \)

4. Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid both scored zero goals in the 2016 UCL final during the extra time.
   - \( \neg Scored(RealMadrid, Atl\u00E9ticoMadrid, ExtraTime()) \land \neg Scored(Atl\u00E9ticoMadrid, RealMadrid, ExtraTime()) \land \text{2016UCLFinal}() \)

### Conclusion:
5. Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid needed to play a penalty shoot-out in the 2016 UCL final.
   - \( NeedPenaltyShootOut(RealMadrid, Atl\u00E9ticoMadrid) \land \text{2016UCLFinal}() \)

These expressions can now be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine if the conclusion follows from the premises.

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['ScoredGoals/3', 'PenaltyShootOut/2', 'RegularTime/1', 'ExtraTime/1', 'UCLFinal/1']

---

Now, let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map:

**Premises:**

1. If two soccer teams score the same number of goals in one UCL final during the regular time, they need to play for the extra time.
   - \( \forall x \forall y (ScoredGoals(x, y, RegularTime(UCLFinal(2016))) \land ScoredGoals(x, y, RegularTime(UCLFinal(2016))) = 1 \rightarrow \text{NeedToPlayExtraTime}(x, y)) \)

2. If two soccer teams score the same number of goals in one UCL final during both regular and extra time, they need to play the penalty shoot-out.
   - \( \forall x \forall y (ScoredGoals(x, y, RegularTime(UCLFinal(2016))) = 1 \land ScoredGoals(x, y, ExtraTime(UCLFinal(2016))) = 0 \rightarrow \text{NeedToPlayPenaltyShootOut}(x, y)) \)

3. Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid both scored one goal in the 2016 UCL final during the regular time.
   - \( ScoredGoals(\text{RealMadrid}, \text{AtléticoMadrid}, RegularTime(UCLFinal(2016))) = 1 \)

4. Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid both scored zero goals in the 2016 UCL final during the extra time.
   - \( ScoredGoals(\text{RealMadrid}, \text{AtléticoMadrid}, ExtraTime(UCLFinal(2016))) = 0 \)

**Conclusion:**
- Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid did not need to play a penalty shoot-out in the 2016 UCL final.
  - \( \neg \text{NeedToPlayPenaltyShootOut}(\text{RealMadrid}, \text{AtléticoMadrid}) \)

These expressions can now be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine if the conclusion logically follows from the premises.

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['Company/1', 'HasOfficeIn/2', 'MultinationalCompany/1', 'MusicSoftware/1', 'DifferentCountries/2']

---

Now let's translate the premises and the conclusion into FOL expressions using the given predicate/arity map:

### Premises

1. Ableton has an office in Germany.
   - `HasOfficeIn(Ableton, Germany)`
   
2. Ableton has an office in the USA.
   - `HasOfficeIn(Ableton, USA)`
   
3. USA and Germany are different countries.
   - `DifferentCountries(USA, Germany)`
   
4. Any company that has offices in different countries is a multinational company.
   - `∀x (Company(x) ∧ HasOfficeIn(x, A) ∧ HasOfficeIn(x, B) ∧ DifferentCountries(A, B) → MultinationalCompany(x))`
   
5. Ableton makes music software.
   - `MusicSoftware(Ableton)`

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['BRICS/1', 'ChinesePeople/1', 'IndianPeople/1', 'EmergingEconomy/1', 'From/2', 'Person/1']

---

Now let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map:

**Premises:**
1. China is one of the BRICS, and its economy is emerging.
   - `BRICS(China) ∧ EmergingEconomy(China)`
2. If someone is from China, then they are from a country of BRICS.
   - `From(Person, China) → BRICS(Person)`
3. India is one of the BRICS, and its economy is emerging.
   - `BRICS(India) ∧ EmergingEconomy(India)`
4. If someone is from India, then they are in a country of BRICS.
   - `From(Person, India) → BRICS(Person)`
5. All people from China are Chinese people.
   - `∀x (From(x, China) → ChinesePeople(x))`
6. All people from India are Indian people.
   - `∀x (From(x, India) → IndianPeople(x))`
7. There is a person from India.
   - `∃x (From(x, India))`

**Conclusion:**
- No people from BRICS are Indian people.
  - `∀x (BRICS(x) → ¬IndianPeople(x))`

These FOL expressions can now be evaluated using a theorem prover like Prover9.

prompt:
The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['BRICS/1', 'ChinesePeople/1', 'EconomyIsEmerging/1', 'FromChina/1', 'FromIndia/1', 'IndianPeople/1']

Now let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map:

### Premises:
1. **China is one of the BRICS, and its economy is emerging.**
   - `BRICS(China) ∧ EconomyIsEmerging(China)`

2. **If someone is from China, then they are from a country of BRICS.**
   - `FromChina(x) → BRICS(x)`

3. **India is one of the BRICS, and its economy is emerging.**
   - `BRICS(India) ∧ EconomyIsEmerging(India)`

4. **If someone is from India, then they are in a country of BRICS.**
   - `FromIndia(x) → BRICS(x)`

5. **All people from China are Chinese people.**
   - `FromChina(x) → ChinesePeople(x)`

6. **All people from India are Indian people.**
   - `FromIndia(x) → IndianPeople(x)`

7. **There is a person from India.**
   - `∃x FromIndia(x)`

### Conclusion:
1. **India's economy is not emerging.**
   - `¬EconomyIsEmerging(India)`

These expressions can now be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.

TEXT: All woodware is dispensable.

TEXT: All paper is woodware.

TEXT: No good things are bad.

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['AwardsTuringAward/2', 'ContributionsAnalysisOfAlgorithms/1', 'ContributionsArtificialIntelligence/1', 'ContributionsNumericalMethods/1']

---

Now, let's translate the premises and the conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map:

### Premises

1. The Turing Award has been awarded to Donald Knuth, Marvin Minsky, Richard Hamming, and John McCarthy.
   - `AwardsTuringAward(TuringAward, DonaldKnuth)`
   - `AwardsTuringAward(TuringAward, MarvinMinsky)`
   - `AwardsTuringAward(TuringAward, RichardHamming)`
   - `AwardsTuringAward(TuringAward, JohnMcCarthy)`

2. Donald Knuth made contributions to the analysis of algorithms.
   - `ContributionsAnalysisOfAlgorithms(DonaldKnuth)`

3. Marvin Minsky is recognized for his contributions to the field of artificial intelligence.
   - `ContributionsArtificialIntelligence(MarvinMinsky)`

4. Richard Hamming researched numerical methods.
   - `ContributionsNumericalMethods(RichardHamming)`

5. John McCarthy made contributions to the field of artificial intelligence.
   - `ContributionsArtificialIntelligence(JohnMcCarthy)`

### Conclusion

- At least two people who have won the Turing Award worked in artificial intelligence.
  - `Exist(x, y, (AwardsTuringAward(TuringAward, x) ∧ ContributionsArtificialIntelligence(x) ∧ AwardsTuringAward(TuringAward, y) ∧ ContributionsArtificialIntelligence(y) ∧ Different(x, y)))`

---

These FOL expressions can now be input into a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine if the conclusion logically follows from the premises.

#### Premises:

#### Conclusion:

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['Album/1', 'IsRapper/1', 'IsOperaSinger/1', 'RapAlbum/1', 'Released/2']
---
Now let's translate the premises and the conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map:

### Premises

1. Tyga is a rapper.
   - `IsRapper(Tyga)`

2. Rappers release rap albums.
   - `∀x (IsRapper(x) → ∃y (Album(y) ∧ Released(x, y) ∧ RapAlbum(y)))`

3. Tyga released the Well Done 3 album.
   - `Released(Tyga, WellDone3)`

4. Rappers are not opera singers.
   - `∀x (IsRapper(x) → ¬IsOperaSinger(x))`

### Conclusion

5. Well Done 3 is a rap album.
   - `RapAlbum(WellDone3)`

These FOL expressions can now be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.

The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['OccurIn/2', 'MonkeypoxVirus/1', 'Beings/1', 'Animals/1', 'Mammals/1', 'Human/1', 'SymptomsOf/2', 'Tired/1', 'FeelTired/2', 'Flu/1']

---

Let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map:

### Premises:
1. `∀x (MonkeypoxVirus(x) → MayGetMonkeypox(x))`
2. `∃x (OccurIn(MonkeypoxVirus, x))`
3. `Human ⊆ Beings`
4. `Mammals ⊆ Animals`
5. `∀x (OccurIn(MonkeypoxVirus, x) → Animal(x))`
6. `∀x (SymptomsOf(MonkeypoxVirus, x) ↔ (Fever(x) ∧ Headache(x) ∧ MusclePains(x) ∧ Tiredness(x)))`
7. `FeelTired(x, Flu)`

### Conclusion:
`∃x (Animal(x))`

These translations can be input into a theorem prover like Prover9 to check if the conclusion logically follows from the premises.

['FourSided/1', 'Shape/1']

### Conclusion:

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['Human/1', 'Horse/1', 'HasHooves/1']

---

Now, let's translate the premises and the conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map:

### Premises:
1. All horses have hooves.
   - \(\forall x (Horse(x) \rightarrow HasHooves(x))\)

2. No humans have hooves.
   - \(\forall x (Human(x) \rightarrow \neg HasHooves(x))\)

### Conclusion:
3. Some humans are horses.
   - \(\exists x (Human(x) \land Horse(x))\)

These expressions can now be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.

prompt:
The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['Animal/1', 'EggLayingMammal/1', 'Hyrax/1', 'Mammal/1', 'Platypus/1', 'Echidna/1', 'Vertebrate/1', 'Invertebrate/1']

Now let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map.

**Premises:**
1. The only types of mammals that lay eggs are either platypuses or echidnas.
   - \( \forall x (EggLayingMammal(x) \rightarrow (x = Platypus \lor x = Echidna)) \)

2. Platypuses are not hyrax.
   - \( Platypus(x) \rightarrow \neg Hyrax(x) \)

3. Echidnas are not hyrax.
   - \( Echidna(x) \rightarrow \neg Hyrax(x) \)

4. No mammals are invertebrates.
   - \( \forall x (Mammal(x) \rightarrow \neg Invertebrate(x)) \)

5. All animals are either vertebrates or invertebrates.
   - \( \forall x (Animal(x) \rightarrow (Vertebrate(x) \lor Invertebrate(x))) \)

6. Mammals are animals.
   - \( \forall x (Mammal(x) \rightarrow Animal(x)) \)

7. Hyraxes are mammals.
   - \( \forall x (Hyrax(x) \rightarrow Mammal(x)) \)

8. Grebes lay eggs.
   - \( \forall x (Grebe(x) \rightarrow EggLayingMammal(x)) \)

9. Grebes are not platypuses and also not echidnas.
   - \( \forall x (Grebe(x) \rightarrow \neg Platypus(x)) \land \forall x (Grebe(x) \rightarrow \neg Echidna(x)) \)

**Conclusion:**
1. Grebes are not mammals.
   - \( \forall x (Grebe(x) \rightarrow \neg Mammal(x)) \)

These expressions can now be input into a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['ArtPiece/1', 'RequirePractice/2', 'RequireTalent/2']

---

Now, let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map.

### Premises
1. Not all art pieces require talent.
   - \(\neg (\forall x \, ArtPiece(x) \rightarrow RequireTalent(x))\)
   - Equivalently: \(\exists x \, ArtPiece(x) \land \neg RequireTalent(x)\)

2. Everything that requires talent requires practice.
   - \(\forall x \, (ArtPiece(x) \land RequireTalent(x) \rightarrow RequirePractice(x))\)

### Conclusion
- There exist art pieces that do not require practice.
  - \(\exists x \, ArtPiece(x) \land \neg RequirePractice(x)\)

These expressions can now be input into a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.

The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['Hungry/1', 'Uncomfortable/1', 'Unhappy/1']

---

Now, let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions using the provided predicate/arity map:

### Premises:
1. If a person is hungry, the person is uncomfortable.
   - \( \text{Hungry}(x) \rightarrow \text{Uncomfortable}(x) \)

2. If a person is uncomfortable, the person is unhappy.
   - \( \text{Uncomfortable}(x) \rightarrow \text{Unhappy}(x) \)

### Conclusion:
3. If a person is not hungry, the person is unhappy.
   - \( \neg \text{Hungry}(x) \rightarrow \text{Unhappy}(x) \)

These FOL expressions can now be evaluated using a theorem solver like Prover9.

prompt:
The following is a first-order logic (FOL) problem.
The problem is to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
The premises are given in the form of a set of first-order logic sentences.
The conclusion is given in the form of a single first-order logic sentence.
The task is to translate each of the premises and conclusions into FOL expressions so that the expressions can be evaluated by a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.
Expressions should adhere to the format of the Python NLTK package logic module.

Predicate/arity map for the problem:
['Fun/1', 'Dreadful/1', 'Surprise/1', 'Scare/1']

---
Now, let's translate the premises and conclusion into FOL expressions:

**Premises:**
1. Surprises are either fun or dreadful.
   - \( \forall x ( \text{Surprise}(x) \rightarrow ( \text{Fun}(x) \lor \text{Dreadful}(x) ) ) \)
2. All scares are surprises.
   - \( \forall x ( \text{Scare}(x) \rightarrow \text{Surprise}(x) ) \)

**Conclusion:**
- \( \forall x ( \text{Scare}(x) \rightarrow \text{Fun}(x) ) \)

These expressions can now be input into a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine whether the conclusion follows from the premises.

<CONCLUSION>

</CONCLUSION>
<EVALUATE>
Predicate/arity map for the problem: 
 ['Bad/1', 'Dispensable/1', 'EnvironmentFriendly/1', 'Good/1', 'Paper/1', 'Woodware/1']TEXT: All dispensable things are environment-friendly. 
FOL: all x. (Dispensable(x) -> EnvironmentFriendly(x))
TEXT: All woodware is dispensable.
FOL: all x. (Woodware(x) -> Dispensable(x))
TEXT: All paper is woodware.

TEXT: No good things are bad.

TEXT: All environment-friendly things are good.
FOL: all x. (EnvironmentFriendly(x) -> Good(x))
TEXT: A worksheet is either paper or is environment-friendly.
FOL: ((Paper(Worksheet) & -EnvironmentFriendly(Worksheet)) | (-Paper(Worksheet) & EnvironmentFriendly(Worksheet)))
TEXT: A worksheet is not dispensable.
FOL: -Dispensable(Worksheet)
</EVALUATE>

### Premises:

These expressions can be input into a theorem solver like Prover9 to determine if the conclusion logically follows from the premises.
